Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Cavity-Enhanced Direct Frequency Comb Spectroscopy: A Multi-Species Technology for Fingerprinting Fugitive Emissions
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will be a pivotal step towards the development of the first commercial analyzer based on Cavity-Enhanced Direct Frequency Comb Spectroscopy (CE-DFCS). This new technique overcomes the traditional divide between narrow-band, highly specific, laser-based techniques and broadband, low-resolution, multi-species methods. CE-DFCS offers the advantages of both categories in a single instrument, opening a realm of possibilities. For the proposed application of fugitive emissions monitoring, CE-DFCS will help to obtain valuable data to better understand and mitigate methane emissions from both agricultural activities and natural gas leakage. The latter issue represents an enormous problem that not only accelerates climate change, but also causes millions of dollars in economic losses and represents a risk to public safety. These issues will drive an increasing market for this type of monitoring technology: the approximately $50 million current market could potentially double within five years. Beyond this application, the versatility and capability inherent in CE-DFCS will also make it widely applicable to other industries, e.g. for real-time process control and chemometrics, where it can ultimately displace complex instruments such as Fourier transform spectrometers and gas chromatographs.

The intellectual merit of this project is finding a pathway to making CE-DFCS sufficiently robust for portable precision measurements in climate research and pollution mitigation. This technology represents a major change from present day spectroscopic technologies, such as Tunable Diode Laser, Cavity Ring-Down, and Fourier Transform Spectroscopy. The resulting instrument will allow researchers and industry to more precisely identify and quantify emissions from pipelines, wells, farms, landfills, forests, swamps, and other sources. While experiments from academia have demonstrated that CE-DFCS has great potential for this application, little work has focused on robustness necessary for field use. Phase I research will focus on the critical need for long-term stability in the coupling between the frequency comb and the optical enhancement cavity, which must be impervious to vibrations and environmental changes to a much higher degree than previously demonstrated. Therefore, the research objective is to properly design, integrate and optimize the electronics with a commercial optical cavity, for robust and self-optimizing comb-cavity coupling. With the proposed design and optimized control parameters and feedback mechanics, excellent long-term stability and vibration resistance is anticipated. The obtained results will serve as a basis to further develop and optimize CE-DFCS for commercial applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nowadays, optical spectroscopy is an indispensable analytical tool for countless applications, ranging from fundamental science to industry and security. By looking at the interaction of molecules with light, substances can be identified and quantified via their unique optical fingerprint. The most common techniques use either a single-frequency laser, targeting one specific molecule, or a broadband light source to obtain information about a sample containing many different molecules. Laser-based absorption spectroscopy is known to deliver the best sensitivity and precision, while broadband spectroscopy allows better flexibility and multi-species detection capability. With the advent of new scientific challenges and innovative industrial processes, more and more applications push the limits of these contemporary analytical techniques. Such applications include, for instance, the analysis of molecular interactions in the atmosphere, the precise control of complex gas mixtures in modern semiconductor manufacturing and the real-time monitoring of chemical processes.

In this Phase I SBIR Project, Tiger Optics addresses these limitations by taking the first important steps to commercializing a new spectroscopic method, Cavity-Enhanced Frequency Comb (CEFC) Spectroscopy. CEFC combines the advantages of both laser-based and broadband spectroscopic techniques, by using a wide-bandwidth laser source, known as the frequency comb. A spectroscopy system based on this innovative laser source combines broadband multi-species detection with high sensitivity and precision, transcending the capabilities of today’s spectroscopic systems.

To make this technology commercially successful, Tiger Optics aims to turn CEFC from research laboratory proof-of-concept into a robust and user-friendly tool for research and industrial applications. The key obstacle here is unmanned operation, which means that the system must perform without continuous attention from a human operator, unlike present lab systems.

Two crucial components of a CEFC system are a frequency comb laser source and a high-finesse external enhancement cavity, which also contains the sample gas. The cavity allows the light to bounce back and forth and interact with the sample many times to boost detection sensitivity, something that is not possible with conventional broadband light sources. The comb and the cavity must be controlled precisely to make sure that the light from the comb is coupled efficiently to the cavity containing the gas sample. In this Phase I SBIR Project, Tiger Optics successfully demonstrated that a combination of electronic control mechanisms and select software algorithms can perform all necessary steps that typically required human intervention. Furthermore, the software is capable of recognizing a system fault and re-initializing the coupling, should an error occur, which is critical to ensure long-term operation. As a result, Tiger Optics was able to overcome one of the key hurdles on the path to commercialization of CEFC Spectroscopy. The research carried out in the Phase I Project provides a strong basis for future work, which will continue on a path to developing a full commercial broadband CEFC Spectroscopy system able to meet complex analytical challenges posed by modern applications in science and industry.
